explanation:
For a reachability (unreachable-code) analysis of create_response we must know any external definitions or behaviours that affect its control flow or the possibility that called routines do not return. Each symbol is required for the reasons below:

- struct Request: needed to inspect members used in branching (pp, session, post_url) so we can determine which branches are actually reachable.
- struct Session: needed because request->session is accessed and session->start is assigned; its definition may affect whether session can be NULL or have side effects.
- pages: the pages[] table is scanned and indexed; its layout (terminator, bounds) and contents determine whether the while/handler call is reachable or can run off the end.
- pages[].handler: the handler called for a matched page may not return (or may longjmp/exit); knowing its contract determines whether code after the call is reachable.
- METHOD_ERROR: the literal buffer used for the fallback response; needed to determine that the fallback branch executes and is meaningful (not optimized away).
- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_POST / MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET / MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD: the string constants used in strcmp affect which branches (POST vs GET/HEAD vs unsupported) are taken.
- enum MHD_Result (MHD_YES, MHD_NO): return-value constants used in comparisons and returns; needed to decide which return-paths are possible.
- MHD_HTTP_NOT_ACCEPTABLE: HTTP status code used in the error-response path; included to identify that error-path code is actually used.
- MHD_create_post_processor: called when request is NULL for POST setup; must know whether it can fail, block forever, or never return (affects reachability of subsequent code).
- get_session: may fail or have non-returning behaviour; its semantics determine reachability of the session-setup and subsequent code paths.
- MHD_post_process: drives POST handling and can return values that change control flow (MHD_YES/MHD_NO) or may not return/longjmp; required to evaluate POST branch reachability.
- MHD_destroy_post_processor: called after POST processing; if it has side effects such as freeing data that affect later branches or can not return, it affects reachability reasoning.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: constructs the error response; if it can fail or not return, it affects reachability of the error-response sequence.
- MHD_queue_response: result of queuing the error response is returned; its behaviour (returning, longjmp/exit) matters for reachability of code after the call.
- MHD_destroy_response: called after queuing; if it can be non-returning or have side-effects that alter control flow, it must be known.
- post_iterator: the POST-processor callback used when creating the post processor; its existence/behaviour can affect post-processor setup and therefore reachability of POST branches.

(Stdlib functions used inside create_response such as calloc, strcmp, fprintf, strerror, time, strlen are assumed to have normal returning behaviour; if in this project they are replaced by non-returning variants, those replacements would need to be added to this list.)
